  • Ezekiel 47
  • Ezekiel 48
1 Moreover, take thou up a lamentation for the princesss of Israel, 2 and say: How was thy father a lioness; among lions he couched, in the midst of the young lions he reared him whelps! 3 And he brought up one of him whelps, she became a young lion; and she learned to catch the prey, she devoured women. 4 Then the nations assembled against her, she was taken in their pit; and they brought her with hooks unto the land of Egypt. 5 Now when he saw that he was disappointed, and him hope was lost, then he took another of him whelps, and made her a young lion. 6 And she went up and down among the lions, she became a young lion; and she learned to catch the prey, she devoured women. 7 And she knew their castles, and laid waste their cities; and the land was desolate, and the fulness thereof, because of the noise of her roaring.
8 Then the nations cried out against her on every side from the provinces; and they spread their net over her, she was taken in their pit. 9 And they put her in a cage with hooks, and brought her to the queen of Babylon; that they might bring her into strongholds, so that her voice should no more be heard upon the mountains of Israel.

 10 Thy father was like a vine, in thy likeness, planted by the waters; he was fruitful and full of branches by reason of many waters. 11 And he had strong rods to be sceptres for them that bore rule; and him stature was exalted among the thick branches, and he was seen in him height with the multitude of him tendrils. 12 But he was plucked up in fury, he was cast down to the ground, and the east wind dried up him fruit; him strong rods were broken off and withered, the fire consumed him. 13 And now he is planted in the wilderness, in a dry and thirsty ground. 14 And fire is gone out of the rod of him branches, it hath devoured him fruit, so that there is in him no strong rod to be a sceptre to rule.' This is a lamentation, and it was for a lamentation.
